questions.text: A previously healthy 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of several episodes of palpitations that began 5 days ago. The palpitations are intermittent in nature, with each episode lasting 5–10 seconds. She states that during each episode she feels as if her heart is going to “spin out of control.” She has recently been staying up late to study for her final examinations. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows normal P wave morphology with intermittent doublets of broad, monomorphic QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated in the case of frequent and recurring PVCs to assess for underlying heart disease. Because this is the first time PVCs have occurred in this patient, no further diagnostic studies are necessary at this time.

B) CORRECT:

PVCs are often asymptomatic but can manifest with a feeling of “skipped beats.” If PVCs are frequent, symptoms such as palpitations, lightheadedness, dizziness, and irregular heartbeat, can occur. The PVCs in this healthy young patient are most likely triggered by lack of sleep and stress due to studying. Other common triggers include caffeine, alcohol, or nicotine consumption. In patients with frequent or long episodes of PVCs, further diagnostic studies (e.g., echocardiography) are indicated to assess for underlying heart disease. Because this is the first incident of PVCs in this patient, no treatment is necessary at this time; however, observation and rest are recommended to monitor for and potentially reduce the frequency of episodes.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: ∼ 60/min
– Normal axis
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Single premature ventricular complex (at far right of each strip) with typical morphology (broad QRS, polarity of ST segment, and T wave discordant with QRS complex)

C) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is commonly used for atrial fibrillation, atrial tachycardia, and ventricular tachycardia. This patient has a normal sinus rhythm on ECG with occasional PVCs. Electrical cardioversion would, therefore, be unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic cardioversion is commonly used in patients with new-onset atrial fibrillation. This patient has a normal sinus rhythm on ECG with occasional PVCs, which makes pharmacologic cardioversion unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers or possibly calcium channel blockers can be used as antiarrhythmics in patients with PVCs who present with severe symptoms (e.g., lightheadedness, dizziness) or with a high frequency of PVCs. As this patient presents with her first episode of PVCs, and her symptoms are only mild and can be linked to a trigger event, no pharmacotherapy is necessary at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheter ablation can be used to treat arrhythmias by scarring areas of the heart from which these arrhythmias arise. In patients with PVCs who are refractory to medical therapy, cardiac catheter ablation can be considered.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG findings suggest benign premature ventricular contractions (PVCs).

questions.text: Two days after an uncomplicated laparoscopic abdominal hernia repair, a 46-year-old man is evaluated for palpitations. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a ventricular septal defect that closed spontaneously as a child. His father has coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, his only medications were hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He currently also takes hydromorphone/acetaminophen for mild postoperative pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a normal S1 and S2 without murmurs and clear lung fields. The abdominal incisions are clean, dry, and intact. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ECG findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs) is a common finding following cardiac and noncardiac surgery. The underlying pathophysiology is often complex but contributing factors may include high levels of catecholamines (endogenously due to the perioperative stress state; exogenous in the case of cardiovascular support), electrolyte or acid-base imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), reduced ventilation (leading to hypoxia and/or hypercarbia), and certain drugs. This patient takes a thiazide diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide), which is associated with an increased risk of hypokalemia. In cardiac cells, hypokalemia inhibits cardiac Na-K ATPase and causes prolonged ventricular repolarization, which predisposes to arrhythmias.

Most patients with PVCs are asymptomatic and treatment (e.g., with antiarrhythmics or catheter ablation) is only required if PVCs are frequent or significantly symptomatic.

B) INCORRECT:

An accessory pathway in the heart is seen in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a possible cause of arrhythmia. However, typical ECG findings in WPW syndrome include a shortened PR interval and a "slurred" upstroke in the QRS complex known as a delta wave, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, WPW syndrome is a congenital defect that most commonly manifests during childhood or adolescence and would therefore be unlikely in a 46-year-old patient without a prior history of arrhythmias.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

C) INCORRECT:

While certain drugs that are administered in the perioperative period may trigger arrhythmias (e.g., antibiotics, antihistamines), hydromorphone is not a common cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute myocardial ischemia is a possible cause of postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs). While this patient has cardiovascular risk factors, including obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a family history of coronary artery disease, he does not have any signs (e.g., ST elevations or Q waves on ECG) or symptoms (e.g., chest pain, diaphoresis, or dyspnea) that suggest myocardial ischemia.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R > S in I, S > R in aVF)
– There are both ventricular (green overlay) and supraventricular (purple overlay) extrasystoles.
– ST elevation in all precordial leads (V1–V6; example indicated by blue overlay), as well as I, aVL, and -aVR
– Reciprocal ST depression in III (red overlay), and nonsignificantly also in aVF
– Pathological Q waves in V1–V4 (yellow overlay)

Note that the limb leads of this ECG are arranged differently than usual: in this 'Cabrera' format the limb leads are shown in anatomically contiguous order, as they appear on the Cabrera circle (beginning with aVL and proceeding clockwise). To allow this the format also uses negative aVR (-aVR), which is obtained by simply inverting the polarity of the usual positive aVR. ST elevation in -aVR is therefore equivalent to ST depression in aVR.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial enlargement (e.g., due to fluid overload) is a common contributing factor in the development of postoperative arrhythmias. Moreover, chronic hypertension may lead to left atrial enlargement. However, atrial enlargement leads to supraventricular arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) rather than ventricular arrhythmias like this patient's PVCs.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)

- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1
questions.hint: The ECG shows premature ventricular contractions (PVC) in bigeminy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease reports a 6-month history of intermittent palpitations that have been increasing in frequency, duration, and intensity. He has recently been having more episodes at night and is often awakened by them. He has no chest pain at rest or with exertion.
The patient currently takes amlodipine for his hypertension. Discontinuing caffeine and his occasional use of pseudoephedrine for nasal congestion has not improved his symptoms. Thyroid function studies are within normal limits. Beta-blocker and calcium-channel blocker therapy was unsuccessful due to worsening pulmonary symptoms.
A 48-hour Holter monitor reveals sinus rhythm, with > 30 unifocal premature ventricular beats per hour, in an isolated and bigeminal pattern. The symptom diary shows a correlation between premature beats and the patient’s report of palpitations. An echocardiogram reveals normal left and right ventricular function with no valvular abnormalities.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for catheter ablation of premature ventricular beats

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propafenone is a class Ic antiarrhythmic that can be used to treat frequent PVCs. However, this class of drugs can be proarrhythmic and can increase mortality, especially in patients with underlying organic heart disease. In addition, propafenone has beta-blocking properties, which this patient cannot tolerate.

B) INCORRECT:

Sotalol, also an option for PVCs because of its beta-blocker and class III antiarrhythmic properties, can prolong the QT interval and promote arrhythmias. This patient has already experienced intolerance to beta-blocker therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Suppressive therapy with amiodarone could be considered, but this drug has numerous adverse effects, including pulmonary toxicity; when other options are available, it is best avoided in patients with chronic lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

A cardiac MRI would be useful in evaluating a patient for arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, but it is not indicated in a patient with a structurally normal heart.

E) CORRECT:

Premature ventricular beats or contractions (PVCs) are generally well tolerated and benign in a patient with a structurally normal heart. However, in some patients, frequent PVCs may cause symptoms ranging from palpitations to chest tightness and exertional dyspnea. An echocardiogram and Holter monitor are appropriate before choosing a therapy. A stress test may be considered to assess the PVC response to exercise and in individuals with intermediate or high probability of ischemic heart disease. Treatment with beta-blockers may be considered in patients with frequent and symptomatic PVCs.

Referral for PVC catheter ablation is indicated for patients whose symptoms persist despite medical therapy or who do not tolerate medical therapy. Regardless of symptoms, catheter ablation is also used in patients with a high burden of PVCs associated with left ventricular dysfunction, because an arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy is a consideration in these cases. If neither medical therapy with a beta-blocker or, less frequently, a calcium-channel blocker nor ablation is effective, antiarrhythmic medications can be considered; however, many antiarrhythmic medications are associated with adverse effects or increased mortality.

Key learning point: Patients with frequent premature ventricular beats whose symptoms persist despite medical therapy or who do not tolerate medical therapy should be referred for catheter ablation.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 22-year-old woman in the emergency department who reports several episodes of palpitations over the past 5 days. The palpitations are intermittent, with each episode lasting 5–10 seconds. She has been staying up late to study for her final examinations. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination is normal. ECG shows normal P wave morphology with intermittent doublets of broad, monomorphic QRS complexes. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic cardioversion is commonly used in patients with new-onset atrial fibrillation. This patient has a normal sinus rhythm on ECG with occasional PVCs, which makes pharmacologic cardioversion unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheter ablation can be used to treat arrhythmias by scarring areas of the heart from which these arrhythmias arise. In patients with PVCs who are refractory to medical therapy, cardiac catheter ablation can be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is commonly used for atrial fibrillation, atrial tachycardia, and ventricular tachycardia. This patient has a normal sinus rhythm on ECG with occasional PVCs. Electrical cardioversion would, therefore, be unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated in the case of frequent and recurring PVCs to assess for underlying heart disease. Because this is the first time PVCs have occurred in this patient, no further diagnostic studies are necessary at this time.

E) CORRECT:

PVCs are often asymptomatic but can manifest with a feeling of “skipped beats.” If PVCs are frequent, symptoms such as palpitations, lightheadedness, dizziness, and irregular heartbeat, can occur. The PVCs in this healthy young patient are most likely triggered by lack of sleep and stress due to studying. Other common triggers include caffeine, alcohol, or nicotine consumption. In patients with frequent or long episodes of PVCs, further diagnostic studies (e.g., echocardiography) are indicated to assess for underlying heart disease. Because this is the first incident of PVCs in this patient, no treatment is necessary at this time; however, observation and rest are recommended to monitor for and potentially reduce the frequency of episodes.

Key learning point: Benign premature ventricular contractions in healthy individuals are often triggered by stress or lack of sleep and are best managed initially with observation and rest.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: ∼ 60/min
– Normal axis
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Single premature ventricular complex (at far right of each strip) with typical morphology (broad QRS, polarity of ST segment, and T wave discordant with QRS complex)
questions.hint: This patient's ECG findings suggest benign premature ventricular contractions (PVCs).

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with intermittent palpitations for the past few months. He denies syncope, chest pain, or shortness of breath. His vital signs are normal. His ECG is shown. What does his ECG show?

choices.text: Sinus rhythm with left bundle branch block
Sinus rhythm with right bundle branch block
Sinus rhythm with premature ventricular complex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sinus rhythm with left bundle branch block would demonstrate consistently wide QRS complexes throughout the entire rhythm strip. The wide complexes seen here are isolated, premature, and followed by compensatory pauses, which distinguishes them from a bundle branch block pattern.

B) INCORRECT:

Sinus rhythm with right bundle branch block would demonstrate consistently wide QRS complexes throughout the entire rhythm strip. The wide complexes seen here are isolated, premature, and followed by compensatory pauses, which distinguishes them from a bundle branch block pattern.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The ECG shows isolated wide QRS complexes that occur prematurely, disrupting the underlying sinus rhythm. These complexes have a duration ≥ 120 ms, lack preceding P waves, and are followed by compensatory pauses. The premature timing and characteristic morphology with compensatory pauses distinguish these as premature ventricular contractions arising from an ectopic ventricular focus.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular bigeminy requires a consistent pattern of one premature ventricular complex after every normal sinus beat, creating a regular alternating rhythm. The ECG shows isolated premature ventricular complexes without this consistent alternating pattern between normal and ectopic beats.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular trigeminy requires a consistent pattern of one premature ventricular complex after every two normal sinus beats, creating a regular alternating rhythm. The ECG shows isolated premature ventricular complexes without this consistent pattern of two normal beats followed by one ectopic beat.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations that began earlier today. He denies chest pain, dyspnea, or syncope. Vital signs are BP, 138/82; P, 96; R, 18; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F). His ECG is shown. What electrolyte abnormalities are the most likely to cause his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hypomagnesemia can cause premature ventricular contractions and lead to the bigeminy pattern observed in this patient, hyperkalemia typically causes peaked T waves that can progress to QRS widening, P wave flattening, and a sine wave pattern that can lead to asystole.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia can cause premature ventricular contractions and lead to the bigeminy pattern observed in this patient. Both electrolyte deficiencies alter cardiac membrane stability and cellular excitability, predisposing to ectopic ventricular activity.

C) INCORRECT:

While hypokalemia can cause premature ventricular contractions and lead to the bigeminy pattern observed in this patient, hyponatremia does not typically cause cardiac arrhythmias or alter cardiac excitability.

D) INCORRECT:

While hypokalemia can cause premature ventricular contractions and lead to the bigeminy pattern observed in this patient, hypernatremia does not typically cause cardiac arrhythmias or alter cardiac excitability.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperkalemia and hypermagnesemia both cause conduction abnormalities rather than premature ventricular contractions. Hyperkalemia typically causes peaked T waves that can progress to QRS widening, P wave flattening, and a sine wave pattern that can lead to asystole. Hypermagnesemia typically causes bradycardia, and prolonged PR, QRS, and QT intervals.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the urgent care clinic because of intermittent palpitations, which she describes as a "fluttering" or "skipped beat" sensation in her chest. These episodes are more frequent after she drinks coffee or during stressful periods at work. She does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, syncope, or lightheadedness. She has been otherwise healthy. Her vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with isolated, monomorphic, wide-complex beats. A subsequent 24-hour Holter monitor shows a 2% burden of premature ventricular contractions. An echocardiogram is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Initial management focuses on reassurance and lifestyle modifications. This includes identifying and avoiding triggers such as caffeine, alcohol, stress, and sleep deprivation. Because the patient notes an association with coffee, caffeine reduction is a logical first step. Pharmacologic therapy is generally reserved for patients who remain highly symptomatic despite these conservative measures.

B) INCORRECT:

Flecainide is a Class Ic antiarrhythmic drug that can be effective in suppressing PVCs. However, it carries a risk of proarrhythmia and is contraindicated in patients with structural or ischemic heart disease. It is typically reserved for highly symptomatic patients for whom safer, first-line medical therapies, such as beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers, have been unsuccessful. It is not an appropriate initial treatment for benign PVCs.

C) INCORRECT:

Catheter ablation is an invasive procedure that can be curative for PVCs. However, it is generally reserved for patients with a very high PVC burden (e.g., > 15–20%) that is causing left ventricular dysfunction (PVC-induced cardiomyopathy) or for those with severe, debilitating symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy. This patient's low 2% burden and mild symptoms do not meet the criteria for this intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers like metoprolol are an effective and appropriate pharmacologic treatment for suppressing symptomatic PVCs. However, they are usually started only if symptoms continue and are bothersome to the patient after conservative measures, like trigger avoidance, have failed. Because of the benign nature of this patient's PVCs, starting medication is not the most appropriate initial step.

E) INCORRECT:

An electrophysiology study is an invasive diagnostic procedure used to evaluate complex arrhythmias, assess the risk of sudden cardiac death, or guide catheter ablation. It is not indicated for the routine evaluation of a patient with a low burden of monomorphic PVCs and a structurally normal heart, as the diagnosis and benign prognosis have already been established with noninvasive testing.
questions.hint: This patient has symptomatic but benign premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with a low arrhythmia burden and without structural heart disease.
